Fales Library and Special Collections
Ursule Molinaro Papers
Molinaro, Ursule
MSS.514
12.5 linear feet in 12 record cartons and 1 manuscript box
1.27 Gigabytes
1942-2004 Ursule Molinaro (1916-2000) was a poet, playwright, and visual artist who moved from France to New York City in the early 1950s to be a translator at the United Nations. Molinaro began publishing her writing in the 1960s and taught classes on creative writing before her death on July 10, 2000. This collection consists of correspondence between 1942 and 2004, as well as manuscripts of novels, plays, short stories. Materials also include flyers and other ephemera promoting Molinaro's writing and painting, audiovisual recordings of Molinaro reading her work, and photographic prints, negatives, and slides. Materials primarily in English, with some publications in French and German. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
The collection includes correspondence, ephemera, and manuscripts of novels, plays, and short stories by Ursule Molinaro between 1963 and 1997. Molinaro's manuscripts focus on reimagining Greek myths to give the female characters individual agency to escape the social strictures of their society. Ursule's writing material ranges from early research and handwritten notes to the final published books and plays. Her correspondence, from 1942 to 2000, are about translations and contracts related to publishing her writing and exhibiting her paintings. The collection also includes flyers, brochures promoting Ursule Molinaro's writing and painting from 1981 to 1994, and photographic prints, negatives, and slides. Audiovisual recordings of Molinaro reading her work as well as performances by contemporary artists she admired, like Arlo Guthrie and Ursula K. Le Guin, are included in the Ursule Molinaro Papers.
Biographical Note
Ursule Molinaro (1916-2000) was a poet, playwright, and visual artist who moved from France to New York City in 1949 and became a translator at the United Nations in 1951. She taught classes on creative writing at New York University and the University of Hawaii. She began publishing her writing in the 1960s and much of her work focuses on reimagining Greek myths for a contemporary audience. Molinaro died in New York City on July 10, 2000.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Bruce Benderson, 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2017.184
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Ursule Molinaro Papers; MSS 514; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, materials were placed in new acid-free folders and boxes maintaining the original order of the records as maintained by Bruce Benderson. Original folder titles were retained...
Described on the collection-level with a box and folder-list.
Born-digital materials on CD-Rs were identified, inventoried, and physically removed from their original boxes, but have not yet been forensically imaged or analyzed. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
